entry.title: Letter 35
entry.content:
Hi, friends. This one is going to be a little different! Different because things are weird and bad right now, and it is hard to make something and put it out into our current world without acknowledging that. So here are some recommendations from us for things you can do to feel less weird and bad, and ways you can help other people who are feeling weird and bad right now.

We recommend

  1. If you‚Äôre still getting paid, donate to someone who isn‚Äôt.

  2. Support local businesses.

  3. Do something with your hands. Water your plants. Tie dye some socks. Clean out your drawers and re-fold all your clothes. Learn how to knit with this helpful guide from Alana Okun. Doodle something on whatever paper you have lying around.

  4. Keep in touch with your creative community by attending online poetry readings, open mics, and workshops from this list compiled by Ariana Brown.

  5. Apply for an absentee ballot.

  6. Make some comfort food. You can find some of our favorite recipes in our Food tag (like this no-knead bread, or these chocolate chip cookies). Bon Appetit has rounded up a ton of recipes for ‚ÄúCooking at Home in the Time of Coronavirus.‚Äù And this collaborative food blog is a joy to scroll through.

  7. Lift the blinds & open the window.

  8. Clean up your space. It‚Äôs easier to feel mentally clear if your space is clear.

  9. Read something‚Äîsomething that‚Äôs not Twitter or pandemic news. Maybe Indoor Voices, a collaborative blog about quarantined life. Or maybe one of the book and poetry recommendations in our Read tag. You might already have your own massive to-read pile, but if you want to buy something new, considering ordering online from a local indie bookstore if you have the option. McNally Jackson, Powell‚Äôs, and Wolfman are some of our favorites that could use your support right now.

  10. Watch Portrait of a Lady on Fire on Hulu.

  11. If you like doing yoga (or if you‚Äôve been meaning to try it!) see if your local yoga studios are doing online classes right now, like Sky Ting Live. And if you have a favorite instructor, consider Venmo-ing them right now.

  12. Find a new routine. Get up and shower in the morning. Put on comfy clothes that are not the ones you slept in. If you‚Äôre working from home, try not to work in your bed. Get up and move around throughout the day. Find an activity to mark the transition from work to leisure time, like listening to a podcast or reading a book. Recognize that this is hard, but you can find small ways to make it easier.

  13. Check in with your friends. Text them, call them, FaceTime them, schedule a Zoom call with them, visit their Animal Crossing island, etc.

entry.title: Letter 34
entry.content:
On patience

In the mornings, I get myself out of bed and into the kitchen, and I turn on the electric kettle to heat up some water, and while the water is heating up I put a small tea strainer into a big mug, and then I pour the hot water over it and I set a timer and wait for the tea to brew for five minutes. And every morning, I know it will take just five minutes. And I know that when the five minutes is up, I‚Äôll have a cup of tea to drink, and I‚Äôll be able to start my day. I am not patient, because to be patient, you have to be ok with waiting for things that are out of your control, and I have a hard time with things that are out of my control. To be patient, you have to be ok with not knowing how things will turn out, and I have a hard time with not knowing how things will turn out. (Are we seeing a pattern here?) I think it is good, if you are an impatient and anxious person like me, to have some things in your life that you can count on, that you know will be there for you on a certain or at a certain time or in a certain place‚Äîthings that you don‚Äôt need to wait for. I am not patient and I don‚Äôt know how to be, but I know that in five minutes, my tea will be ready, and that comforts me.

‚Äì Jillian

I am impatient, I am anxious, I do not like waiting for things; I am always way too early or running late and barely have a concept of how much time has passed. I‚Äôve only begun to focus on managing this in the last two years, and my first step was mastering caramelizing onions. Helen Rosner tweeted once about how all recipes lie to you about how long it takes to caramelize onions. They do! I felt dumb! But they were just lying! In the summer of 2018, I became obsessed with putting them in everything. I didn‚Äôt realize, at first, they would take upwards of an hour to cook, and any impatience in their cooking (bumping up the temperature) would basically lead to burnt onions, instead. But I did it, to varying degrees of success: notably, a quiche I made for a Bachelor in Paradise viewing, had a chorus of ‚Äúoh, Summer, these onions kind of taste caramelized.‚Äù The true first success, though, was when I had a friend coming over to make a meal, had very little else to do beforehand, and just started prepping; I chopped onions, and there was an hour before they would arrive. I put them on the stove. I had no rush, and so I didn‚Äôt need them to be caramel-y sooner. The final meal tasted fantastic. I‚Äôve caramelized onions dozens of times since, some times better than others. A lot of my anxiety comes from thinking I do not have enough time left. I want to learn to give myself that time.

‚Äì Summer

We recommend

üìñ Capable Monsters by Marlin M. Jenkins

There are two things I love‚ÄîPokemon and poems‚Äîso as you‚Äôd expect, this chapbook is perfect for me. Marlin does such a good job at capturing something important to a lot of people, emotionally/mentally/sentimentally (Pokemon) and unraveling its smallest parts into these beautiful reflections that communicate just why it hits so hard. I am a big fan of anything that takes something maybe a little silly and lovingly, enchantingly expands on the ways it contributes to our healing. Buy this book from Bull City.

‚Äì Summer

üì± Threads

I don‚Äôt know why I didn‚Äôt know this app existed until last week, but I have been using it religiously since I first downloaded it. Threads is an app from Instagram just for DMs with the people on your Close Friends list‚Äîthat‚Äôs literally it. It‚Äôs great. I have been trying to spend less time on Instagram because (wow!) it sometimes makes me feel bad and I don‚Äôt like that, but it‚Äôs hard to limit your time on an app that plays a big part in how you communicate with the people you‚Äôre close to. Using Threads to separate my daily DMs from the rest of Instagram has been huge for me, and I definitely recommend it to anyone else who is tired of opening Instagram 80 times a day but still wants to send selfies with silly filters on them to their friends..

‚Äì Jillian

üéôÔ∏è Theme Park Trash

I spent a lot of my childhood in Southern California, about 30 minutes from Disneyland, Universal Studios, Knotts‚Äô Berry Farm, etc. etc. I knew theme park people, I wanted to be theme park people, I could have been theme park people if I‚Äôd had a driver‚Äôs license, and listen: Miya and Rosie are the best kind! They juggle that loving nostalgia and present romanticizing of places like Disneyland with the absolute full knowledge that yes, theme parks are sort of a capitalistic nightmare! Buuuuuut they‚Äôre really fun, and we can give ourselves that! Each episode, they discuss topics or imagine scenarios related to theme parks‚Äîlike designing a new ride for Harry Potter World, or planning a perfect Disneyland date. Miya and Rosie are really fucking funny and also incredibly brilliant‚Äîlisten to them here. I‚Äôd recommend starting with one of their recent episodes, ‚ÄúWriting a Mickey Mouse Movie.‚Äù

‚Äì Summer

‚úâÔ∏è Laura Olin‚Äôs newsletter

Laura Olin sends out a newsletter every Thursday with 10 links to nice, lovely things found on the internet, and it makes me feel good every week. Here is this week‚Äôs. I‚Äôll let it speak for itself! If you like it, you should subscribe.

‚Äì Jillian

entry.title: Letter 33
entry.content:
On slowing down

Lately, I have been trying to wake up just a little bit earlier, early enough that I am allowed to spend some extra time in bed with a cup of tea before I need to get up and get ready for work, early enough to have a little bit of breathing room. Maybe I spend that time reading, or watching the pigeons on my balcony, or playing a video game. (Did you know you could play video games in the morning before work? I certainly didn‚Äôt. But you can.) Maybe I spend that time just laying in bed, doing nothing. I am often in a rush, but not in the mornings‚Äîthat is when I am allowed to slow down, take my time, and breathe. Just for an hour, but it‚Äôs my hour. And then I get out of bed, and I get ready for work. And the rest of the day comes fast.

‚Äì Jillian

I‚Äôve always been a fast reader. No one considered it a problem, and it didn‚Äôt become one until I was in my mid-teens, with my brain feeling bad more often than not. One thing depression took from me was comprehension and memory: I was absorbing less and less as I read, struggling more to remember what it had been that I spent an hour doing. It wasn‚Äôt until I was 19 or 20 that I really realized why, when I was in class assigned Jane Austen‚Äôs Emma. My professor emphasized that Austen deserved to be read slowly; I had read two Austen novels before and did not enjoy either of them, couldn‚Äôt really tell you what had happened and blamed the text. But I was a marginally obedient student and cared too much about my grades, so of course I read. And I read slowly, pushing against my instinct. And I enjoyed it. I still couldn‚Äôt tell you small details and did poorly on comprehension quizzes, but my experience was not marked by frustration and confusion which many of my reading experiences had become. I still struggle with instinct, the motivation to do the most, the feeling that I‚Äôm not a good reader if I‚Äôm not cycling through new books every few days. I want to keep slowing down, and keep giving words the time they deserve.

‚Äì Summer

We recommend

üîó Helen Rosner Interviews Samin Nosrat

I love this New Yorker piece for a variety of reasons: Helen and Samin are two of my favorite people in the food world, the photo of Samin‚Äôs sink as she strains pickled beets, the conversation about depression, etc. The moment that struck me the most was Samin reflecting on writing a piece about Persian food for the NYT, then interjecting, ‚Äúbut then, well, it turns out that people can like our food and still want to bomb us.‚Äù You might have noticed, but talking about Palestinian food is one of my main hobbies: watching others (my mom, that one BA video) make it, eating it, sharing it with my friends‚Äîthat‚Äôs joy, that‚Äôs love. I know the people I share my food with already love me, and are already learning about the ways my people are harmed; this is not the case for every patron looking for shawarma. It‚Äôs beautiful to hope someone will taste zaatar and decide they‚Äôre ready to help free Palestine, but that‚Äôs an impossible pressure to place on cuisine. Not only will people eat our food and still bomb us, they‚Äôll take it for their own and pretend we never existed in the first place. There are small ways to curb that, like not buying certain hummus brands, vetting ‚ÄúMediterranean‚Äù restaurants before you go, and so on. Food can be a tool of justice, but never on its own.

‚Äì Summer

üì± Turning off notifications

There is nothing more annoying to me than trying to concentrate on reading an article or playing a game or watching a video on my phone and seeing a bunch of banner notifications pop up to distract me‚Äîso I turned them off. I also turned off push notifications and badges for most of the apps on my phone, so I only get notified for things that really need my attention, like text messages and DMs. Spend some time curating your notification settings this week‚Äîyou deserve a little more quiet.

‚Äì Jillian

üé• Portrait of a Lady on Fire

Portrait of a Lady on Fire, directed by C√©line Sciamma, is perhaps the best romantic film I have ever seen. The subtle eye movements, the tense collarbones, the yearning. The absolute yearning, oh my god. This movie is a beautiful meditation on gaze, with the premise being a woman commissioned to paint a wedding portrait but not let the subject know she is painting her. And then (spoiler?) they fall in love. And it‚Äôs beautiful and tender and there were two scenes that made me cry and I still get goosebumps everywhere when I think about them. Find it in a theater near you.

‚Äì Summer

üìñ Little Weirds by Jenny Slate

I finished reading Jenny Slate‚Äôs book a little over a week ago, but I have not stopped thinking about it. I miss reading it! It was full of nice, small passages that made me feel happy and gentle and tender. The way to read this book, in my opinion, is to wake up a little bit earlier than you need to and spend 5 minutes reading it until you feel good and soft and ready to get out of bed, and then carry that feeling with you for the rest of the day, like taking a daily multivitamin. I underlined so much of this book, but my one very favorite bit was this: ‚ÄúMy vulnerability is natural and permissible and beautiful to me, and it should remind you of your responsibility to behave like a friend to me and the world.‚Äù

‚Äì Jillian

entry.title: Letter 32
entry.content:
On goals

Sometime last year, Summer and another friend and I started a monthly email thread to plan and talk about our goals for the coming month, followed by the occasional video chat for progress updates. We talked about things we wanted to accomplish in our careers, in our personal lives, and in our relationships, but we also talked about our feelings, our anxieties, the things we‚Äôre grateful for, and the things we need help with. What started as a way to voice our goals and desires and to hold each other accountable became a pleasant excuse to catch up with each other and just talk. And I really can‚Äôt overstate how nice that is. We have recommended several methods for setting and tracking goals in this newsletter‚Äîincluding a habit-tracking app, a goal-tracking spreadsheet, a workbook for setting yearly goals, and the app mentioned below‚Äîbut this is the only one that encourages community with people you love.

‚Äì Jillian

Every year, Oscars season approaches, and I tell myself I will watch every film nominated for Best Picture. Sometimes I‚Äôve already seen a handful in theaters, some years I haven‚Äôt seen any at all. This year was less than more, from a combination of disinterest, snubs, and general anxiety at being in Public and Seen. The best I did, before this year, was 2015 when torrenting was my friend (but of course I don‚Äôt do that anymore; I‚Äôm very cool and lawful). I‚Äôm not sure why I love awards shows, but I have since even before I loved to be mad online and wasn‚Äôt familiar with any material being awarded. I watched 15 hours of movies from Wednesday‚ÄìSunday, while still keeping my room relatively clean and putting together a viewing party with my roommate. I still didn‚Äôt see all of the Best Picture nominations, but I was satisfied with my breadth. I set a lot of goals for personal and professional development‚Äîmany that I do not meet‚Äîbut it‚Äôs fun to make something very arbitrary, like a quota of movies, and to achieve it. Goal-setting can be fun. There can be enough time if I make enough time.

‚Äì Summer

We recommend

üé• Pain & Glory

This was part of my Oscars binge, one of the films nominated for Best International Picture‚Äîand Antonio Banderas for Best Actor. Folks! Do you ever watch 14 hours of film directed by straight men and get exhausted, think all movies are just too long, wonder when directors stopped listening to their editors, triggering an existential spiral? And then you watch Pain & Glory, and you are healed? I highly recommend watching this even without the saturation of indulgence beforehand. Antonio Banderas is so good, especially when I realized his most notable role for me is, in fact, Spy Kids. The story follows an aging queer director, reflecting on his past and contending with his present. It is extremely tender, generous with time, and just beautiful. Again, healed. Check it out, hopefully in a theater near you!

‚Äì Summer

üì±Tangerine

I have been using this app for a few months as a beta tester, and I‚Äôm so happy that it is finally out there in the world for everyone else to use! Tangerine combines two of my favorite things‚Äîhabit tracking, and mood tracking‚Äîin a beautiful and easy-to-use way. It‚Äôs made a difference in the way I approach my daily habits and routines, and has quickly become one of my most-used apps. You can download it on the App Store.

‚Äì Jillian

üé• Birds of Prey: The Fantabulous Emancipation of One Harley Quinn

Sorry, I‚Äôm recommending two movies!!!! I‚Äôve really done nothing else since the last letter. So, I truly do not give a fuck about the DCEU, and the sparing few movies I‚Äôve seen from that set have been pretty bad-to-mediocre. And yet! I hate that I‚Äôm basically recommending this movie because #representation, but it was really so fucking fun. A wonderfully talented cast with women of color, queer characters who get to exist besides that, a perfect soundtrack, bright colors and exciting fight scenes‚Ä¶there‚Äôs no reason not to see it! I love to have fun! I would die for Margot Robbie. Ewan McGregor is the best villain. Directed by Cathy Yan. Also in theaters now!

‚Äì Summer

üíå Desk Lunch

I (obviously) love newsletters, and this one is one of my very favorites. Every issue of Desk Lunch is written by a different creative person about their process, their life, their journey, their thoughts. The latest issue, which I read this morning, was so good and relevant to me in particular‚ÄîCarolyn Yoo writes about struggling to answer ‚ÄúThe Question‚Äù of her career path: ‚ÄúPerhaps I would keep searching for what I was meant to do for many more years of my life, but I could learn to embrace the spiral instead of resenting that I hadn‚Äôt reached an answer yet.‚Äù Whew. Subscribe to Desk Lunch for more great stuff like that.

‚Äì Jillian

entry.title: Letter 31
entry.content:
On social media

It‚Äôs time for my scheduled annual spiral about social media‚Äîthat lovely time of year when I wonder what I‚Äôm doing on Instagram and Twitter, what I‚Äôm trying to get out of it, what I should be posting, who I actually care about following, and what it all means. The cycle goes like this: I decide I want to spend less time feeling bad on social media, so I unfollow a bunch of accounts that aren‚Äôt contributing to my life in a meaningful way to clear up my feed and make it easier to less time scrolling and more time seeing only the content I care about; a week later, I get bored and decide I‚Äôm not getting enough out of social media, so I find and follow a bunch of new accounts that are exciting or inspiring to me in some way; then, the cycle continues. Maybe the trick is to make peace with this ebb and flow of being very online, instead of feeling weird and bad about it. Maybe the trick is just not overthinking it. For now, I still don‚Äôt really know what I‚Äôm doing and I still feel very conflicted about the way I use social media‚Äîbut if I figure it out, I‚Äôll let you know.

‚Äì Jillian

I‚Äôve lived most of my life online. I found my first internet friends when I was 10, feeling alone, caring too much about too many things; I‚Äôm 22 now, and sort of the same. My friends are far away, my boyfriend is far away, my family is far away. I‚Äôve loved so many people from such a distance. As social media becomes part of everyone‚Äôs social habits, inextricable from the ‚Äúreal world,‚Äù those friendships are stronger, but they‚Äôre intertwined with everything that sucks. I read about a shooting and wish my friend a happy birthday in the same thought; I read about my people fighting for their freedom and see others celebrating a game before I finish the headline. I never want to be an old man shouting at a cloud. We can all care about so, so many things, and that is how I got here in the first place. I never want to dismiss the lifesaving connections social media has brought me. I don‚Äôt know how to navigate my escapism collapsing into what I escape from, even though it‚Äôs been happening for years‚Äîeven more, I don‚Äôt know how to deal with the fact that I don‚Äôt want to escape anymore. I want to know. I don‚Äôt want distance. From anyone, from anything.

‚Äì Summer

We recommend

üìñ Reconstructions by Bradley Trumpfheller

My friend has a chapbook and it‚Äôs one of the most stunning things you will read in 2020. (I don‚Äôt care that it‚Äôs only January!) Bradley is ridiculously talented. Each of their poems just feels in love with the medium, in love with the page, trying to run off of it‚Äîthere‚Äôs an elegance to the weight of just how impressive their work is. I read it on a plane & studied it for hours after. It deserves so, so much attention. You can buy Reconstructions on the Sibling Rivalry Press website!

‚Äì Summer

üìñ How To Do Nothing

I think everyone should be required to read this book, full stop. I highlighted lines on nearly every page, but here is a favorite, from the introduction, that will give you a sense of what this book is all about: ‚ÄúThe point of doing nothing, as I define it, isn‚Äôt to return to work refreshed and ready to be more productive, but rather to question what we currently perceive as productive.‚Äù This is not just a book about birdwatching and quitting Facebook‚Äîit is a book about collective action and shared public spaces and attention and art and community. If you‚Äôve read it, DM me so we can talk. If you haven‚Äôt, you need to fix that.

‚Äì Jillian

üì∫ High School Musical: The Musical: The Series

When the trailer dropped for this show, all I could think was this is for me. I‚Äôm a survivor of the Glee fandom (as is Jillian), and yes! It did warp my brain! I am hungry for disaster surrounded by a song (this explains why I can‚Äôt stop thinking about CATS (2019), too)! I wanted this show to be like Riverdale, or Nancy Drew, just absurd and a good time and makes you think wait, am I so irony-poisoned that I‚Äôve turned this into my favorite show? BUT! TWIST! This show is actually fucking great! No irony! Full seriousness! It holds all of the camp and cradles it, it acknowledges its predecessors (HSM as much as Glee as much as all other teen comedies), and does so, so good by its teens. Basically everyone gets complexity, everyone gets a full life, they are kind, they are mean, and they are jealous, but never cartoonishly or destructively. They sing well but it doesn‚Äôt feel like, oh ok cool we love 30-year-old Broadway veterans. There are characters of color, there are queer characters (QPOC, even!) There‚Äôs a Palestinian flag! Just! In the background of a scene? Yes, reader, I cried! Watch it on Disney+, my reluctant ally.

‚Äì Summer

üì∫ Shrill

I looked through our archives to see if we had already mentioned this show, because I was sure we had‚Äîbut somehow, no! Which is a problem, because this show is brilliant and funny and makes me feel so good. The second season just came out on Hulu, and we are all so lucky.

‚Äì Jillian

entry.title: Letter 30
entry.content:
On procrastination

It‚Äôs incredibly appropriate that I waited until the very last minute to write this. Like, if you‚Äôre reading this right after it went up, I probably just finished writing this ten minutes ago. Even now, I am doing my very best to avoid writing this by doing other work instead. I would love to say that we draft this newsletter days before we send it out (and sometimes we do!) but more often than not we are scrambling to put it together the day of. You never stop procrastinating, even as an adult‚Äîeven when the thing you are procrastinating is something like doing laundry or making plans with a friend you haven‚Äôt seen in a while, instead of the kinds of things you avoided doing in high school, like math homework and studying for finals. When I was a kid, I thought procrastinating meant I was lazy, or a bad student. I didn‚Äôt learn to recognize it as a symptom of anxiety until later. (And listen: sometimes it‚Äôs both. Sometimes I very much am just lazy.) The only thing I know for sure about procrastination is that it isn‚Äôt the big, scary monster it sometimes feels like; everyone procrastinates, it‚Äôs fine, we‚Äôre all fine, and it will feel so much better once you just do the thing you‚Äôre avoiding.

‚Äì Jillian

I‚Äôm very critical of myself, blame myself for a lot of things that are maybe not fault, suffer from depression‚ÄîI‚Äôm not great at getting things done on time! Leaving school has given me a different perception of time, truly, and the types of tasks I put off, and why I‚Äôm putting them off; starting an assignment was always such a chore, but putting away my laundry is, too, deep-cleaning my room, grocery shopping, all of the above. Nothing is as bad if you just start. I create my own time and deadlines now, and instead of working towards a degree I‚Äôm working towards my health. I don‚Äôt want to put off cleaning my room because then the dust builds up and my lungs hurt, my lungs hurt and I don‚Äôt want to clean, the vicious cycle. I put off writing poems until I feel better. I end up doing almost nothing at all, mechanically going to work, coming home, brushing my teeth, going to bed. Procrastination means something different, less risking a grade and my sense of achievement and more something more severe, but I am doing it less. I am sticking to some schedules, following through in some ways. It feels better to know I can.

‚Äì Summer

We recommend

üìΩÔ∏è Hustlers

I started this movie about ten minutes before the Golden Globes were over, feeling exhausted as I normally do while watching the Golden Globes. While the Oscars nominations didn‚Äôt fix that (Jennifer Lopez robbed! Uncut Gems robbed!), movies are still good! Halfway through, my roommate and I looked at each other and said, ‚ÄúPerhaps this is the best movie ever made? Perhaps, favorite film of all time?‚Äù The needle drops are magical, Jennifer Lopez and Constance Wu are so fucking strong, the supporting cast is brilliant, and just throughout you feel the thriving competence! Motherhood is complex! Fuck the systems that harm you! Women!!!!! Oscar for Lorene Scafaria!!!! It‚Äôs available to rent on a few streaming platforms, but I‚Äôm probably gonna go get the DVD to put into my non-existent DVD player.

‚Äì Summer

üéÆ Pastel Nintendo Switch joycons

This is a very tentative recommendation, because it involves voiding the warranty on your Switch, using tiny screwdrivers to take apart your joycons, messing with the tiny, fragile pieces that make the joycons work, and somehow putting it all back together again properly. I did it, and it took two tries, but it turned out great and now I have a very cute, pastel Switch. Proceed with caution! Do your research! Find tutorials to follow along with! (And probably only do this if you have a backup pair of joycons, lbr.) Oh, and here are the joycon shells, backplate, joystick caps, and button replacements that I used.

‚Äì Jillian

üéôÔ∏è My Year in Mensa

I‚Äôve recommended Jamie Loftus‚Äôs work a few times on this letter, but here we go again! On January 1st she dropped a 4-episode podcast series about her year in the Smart People Club? Eugenics society? Mensa! It is, expectedly, hilarious, but it‚Äôs also a really interesting history, truly riveting because you fear for her safety, and a nice dive into people who think differently than you that, spoiler, doesn‚Äôt end with you being told to sympathize with people who want to cause you harm!

‚Äì Summer

üé∂ Listen to Animal Crossing music while you work

Or while you‚Äôre not working, whatever, that works too. This website plays the Animal Crossing soundtracks from whichever version of the game you want on a constant loop, changing the music depending on the time. Personally, I prefer the original Gamecube soundtrack for maximum nostalgic vibes.

‚Äì Jillian

entry.title: Letter 29
entry.content:
On gratitude

I spent a lot of time thinking about gratitude this year, actually recognizing it as a tool in my life for the first time, actively practicing the act of feeling grateful and letting it transform the way I think and feel. I wrote down the things I am grateful for, and thought about those things, instead of dwelling on what hurt me. I won‚Äôt list all of those things here, but I will say that, above all, I have felt the most grateful for the feeling of home that I have found in my life. Finding gratitude has made me happier‚Äîthat seems like such a simple way of putting it, but it‚Äôs true. Here is a simple thing to do that will have an impact on your life: think about what are you are grateful for today, write it down, say it out loud, commit it to memory, recognize it. Do it again tomorrow, and the next day, and the day after that, etc.

‚Äì Jillian

It‚Äôs the first day of the year & I‚Äôve seen a thousand wrap-up threads full of people‚Äôs accomplishments. I have very little to link people to besides this letter as an object of things I have finished, and I am okay with it. I almost said I didn‚Äôt accomplish anything, but that is not true‚ÄîI wrote a thesis, I was on a slam team, I graduated, I got a job, I was honest with my feelings again & again & again. But really, I am really, truly thankful to be surrounded by an immense amount of talented people. I toyed with doing a gratitude thread, just publicly thanking the dozens of people who made me feel safe & loved in 2019, but it felt silly; I can just tell them personally! In the last year or so, I‚Äôve gotten into the habit of telling people when I think of them even if we haven‚Äôt spoken in a while, generally checking-in by text, etc. I‚Äôm not sure if the practice has improved any of my relationships but it does feel nice to feel free telling people they are on your mind. I want to continue this, push it further. I‚Äôm grateful for my friends, but I want to be specific with it, and everything else moving forward. Tell people you love them!!!!! It‚Äôs so so good!!!

‚Äì Summer

We recommend

üé• Little Women (2019)

I feel bold recommending this without having read the book nor seeing any other adaption, but folks! This movie was a warm hug but also not like, necessarily comforting. Maybe more like a solemn ‚Äúyeah,‚Äù a nod, and a pat on the back. It was beautiful. I am in love with every cast member. I think about Greta Gerwig and all of the discourse her name carries (just ask if you don‚Äôt know, lol) almost constantly these days, and since seeing Little Women my thoughts have been basically all positive. If you were on the fence about seeing it, go have fun! Cry a little! Yearn for poofy skirts & leather bound-books!

‚Äì Summer

üìñ Conversations with Friends by Sally Rooney

Full disclosure: this book destroyed me. I feel like I am the last person on earth to read Conversations with Friends, but I would feel silly not mentioning it in a newsletter about things I love, because I truly loved it. It‚Äôs exactly as good as everyone says, and as soon as I started reading it I could feel all of my friends laughing at me, because it felt like it was engineered in a lab to be exactly the book I needed to read. Maybe it‚Äôs exactly the book you need to read, too.

‚Äì Jillian

üì∫ The Mandalorian

I saw The Rise of Skywalker the day it came out and it was awful, for reasons I do not need to get into right now, but personally the worst part of my viewing was perhaps 3/4ths of the way through when all I could think was, ‚ÄúWait‚Ä¶maybe all Star Wars are bad? Have I been caught in a nostalgia loop since the earlier 2000s?‚Äù But no! Star Wars is good, camp is good, etc etc. And this show! Reinforces how much I love that franchise! It gives a nice look at places in the Star Wars universe without it always being life-or-death and, strangely, explores a very healthy father-son relationship. Pedro Pascal is so good!!!! And he‚Äôs in a big hunk of metal suit the whole time!!!! I WILL die for The Child!!! Watch it on your brother‚Äôs Disney+ account.

‚Äì Summer

üìΩÔ∏è Welcome to Union Glacier

A little over a week ago, I was reading The Abundance, a collection of Annie Dillard essays, and the final chapter was a bit from Teaching a Stone to Talk about Antarctica. Something about the way she wrote about antarctic exploration and expeditions made me hungry for more (isn‚Äôt it fun to get suddenly very into a niche topic like this?) and my boyfriend recommended this documentary about Union Glacier and the small team of people who work there. I watched it on a cold day in my apartment, feeling cozy on the couch with a cup of tea, and I loved it. And please, if you have any of your own recommendations for Antarctica-related content, send it my way.

‚Äì Jillian

entry.title: Letter 28
entry.content:
Our 2019 favorites

It‚Äôs hard to believe we‚Äôve been doing this newsletter for over a year, but here we are! For our last letter of 2019, we took a look back at everything we recommended this year and chose our absolute favorites to revisit. Here are the ten things we still really love‚Äîmaybe you‚Äôll love them too.

We recommend

üçΩ Reem‚Äôs Muhammara Recipe

I talk about Reem‚Äôs all of the time, and I think about this muhammara everyday; I won‚Äôt make it again until I have a bigger food processor, but I treasure the experience, weirdly, of peeling the red bell peppers while they cool down, sort of blistering my hands, knowing how much I truly love making food. You can read my original recommendation here.

‚Äì Summer

üì± Youper

In the past year, I‚Äôve gotten really into journaling and mood tracking, and this app has been my daily companion in both. I loved it when I wrote my original recommendation, and I still love it now.

‚Äì Jillian

üìñ Hard Damage by Aria Aber

I started re-reading this the other day, cementing it as my favorite of 2019; Aria is brilliant and heartbreaking. Buy her book, and read my original recommendation here.

‚Äì Summer

üéâ XOXO

I have gone to Portland for XOXO two years in a row, and I feel very certain that I will continue going every year for as long as possible. When I first shared it in this newsletter, I had just gotten back from my second time attending this weird, wonderful conference, and I was already looking forward to going back. So I‚Äôll say it again: if you have the opportunity, please go.

‚Äì Jillian

üì∫ Polygon‚Äôs Unraveled

Brian David Gilbert continues to make me laugh when I am very, very, sad. The videos just keep getting more elaborate and have given me comfort most consistently throughout 2019. I‚Äôm saying nothing new!

‚Äì Summer

üçΩÔ∏è No-knead bread

I made a lot of bread this year, and almost all of it was this no-knead bread that I am still in love with. It‚Äôs easy, great for beginners, and very delicious. My original recommendation still rings true‚Äîthis bread has never let me down.

‚Äì Jillian

üìñ Kingdom Animalia by Aracelis Girmay

I‚Äôll never shut up about this book! I read it in June and I read it in August and I‚Äôll read it again and again and again and again once I get my own copy! I am chasing that feeling of overwhelmed with every piece of media I engage with and this one will never stop giving. I love it. Read my first recommendation here.

‚Äì Summer

üì± Cute-ify your calendar

If you are using a calendar app (I am using three, because I‚Äôm me) you should put some effort into making it nice to look at. All of my event names have emojis in them, and my calendars are light pinks, purples, and peaches‚Äîbecause default colors are boring!

‚Äì Jillian

üé∂ Rilo Kiley‚Äôs The Execution of All Things

Surprisingly, Rilo Kiley didn‚Äôt end up being one of my Spotify wrapped top 5 artists. However, many of the songs from the album were on my top 100 playlist‚ÄîA Better Son / Daughter near the top. This album came near the end of my 2019 when I truly needed a new way to communicate certain feelings. It helped and it continues to help. If you want my raw, spiral-y reaction, that‚Äôs in Letter 23.

‚Äì Summer

üìñ How to Not Always Be Working by Marlee Grace

This book has stayed with me every day since I read it. If you are struggling under the weight of projects and side-hustles and to-do lists, this book is for you. I mentioned earlier that I took notes while I read it, and I still revisit those notes from time to time, whenever I need to remind myself to take a break from work.

‚Äì Jillian

entry.title: Letter 27
entry.content:
On letting go

I‚Äôm having a hard time articulating why, but I feel calmer than usual lately. December is a weird month‚Äîthere‚Äôs so much I feel like I need to squeeze in before the holidays come and the year ends, but I don‚Äôt feel frantic or anxious about it at all. I sort of feel like, who cares? As I wrote in an email to Summer last week, I just want to do nothing and be comfy until January. I‚Äôm ready to hunker down until the new year comes so I can re-emerge and start over, let go of all the things that aren‚Äôt working for me, make space for gratitude instead of guilt, etc. etc. etc. I‚Äôm trying not to ask too much of myself right now, which probably should not be a December-specific intention, but I‚Äôm welcoming it nonetheless.

‚Äì Jillian

I‚Äôve discovered I do, in fact, keep grudges. I didn‚Äôt super know that about me. I thought I was a cool, chill girl. Nope! The other day I saw a Twitter account of an ex-friend and felt bitter. I saw a different one a few days later and felt the same, then frustrated. We mostly drifted, and yet I was letting the simple act of maybe someone doesn‚Äôt love you make me feel just awful. And now I am giving space to that feeling in this letter, and communicating it to all of you‚ÄîI am very bad at deciding I‚Äôm not going to let this bother me and I don‚Äôt want to talk about this anymore but actually just, talking about it more, only, exclusively, loudly. I want to learn how to process The Bad. I am lucky to have a lot of people in my life who let me shout and complain and encourage my anger, almost, but I feel like a broken record; I can scream about the same thing forever, over and over, mostly because the things I scream about are linked to Bigger World Injustices (lol) but also I‚Äôm not sure how to truly process. Let go. Transform anger or bitterness. I want to figure it out.

‚Äì Summer

We recommend

üìñ Cordite 94: Bayt

Zeina Hashem Beck curated this incredible issue of writers of Arab heritage for Cordite. There are 42 poems, a mini-chapbook, and a few essays. People I love dearly, dearly, dearly have work in this issue and there is very little I love more than poems & my friends. Check it out here!

‚Äì Summer

‚úâÔ∏è Tiny Spells

Tiny Spells is a short, daily newsletter about self care‚Äîand not the use-my-affiliate-link-to-buy-an-essential-oil-diffuser kind of self care. (Valid! But not what we‚Äôre talking about here.) Tiny Spells lands in your inbox every day with three small, manageable things you can do to take care of yourself, like ‚ÄúPlan how you‚Äôre going to get your water intake up,‚Äù ‚ÄúThink about the smells that surround you,‚Äù and ‚ÄúPlease book that doctor‚Äôs appointment you‚Äôve been dodging.‚Äù And if you don‚Äôt need another newsletter, you can find them on Twitter instead.

‚Äì Jillian

üîó Fargo Tbakhi‚Äôs essay ‚ÄúWatching ‚ÄòThe Last Black Man in San Francisco‚Äô as a Palestinian-American‚Äù

I might be double-dipping with the recommendations this week since Fargo also has a poem in the issue above, but listen! My friend is the smartest person in the world. This essay is part of my favorite genre of film writing‚Äîreview by way of personal essay, a synthesis of all of the things we think about when experiencing something wonderful. He does such an incredible job linking so many different types of texts and relaying both the active experience of watching but also the more ever-present desire to relate, connect, map. It‚Äôs a great read regardless of whether or not you‚Äôve seen the movie or whether or not you are Palestinian. Check it out here.

‚Äì Summer

üîó Haley Houseman‚Äôs Tackling 2020 Workbook

I love setting goals, and I love following directions. Naturally, this goal-setting guide by the brilliant Haley Houseman is my new favorite thing. It is extremely thorough, and was made to walk you through the process of reflecting on 2019 and setting yourself up for a good 2020, whatever that means for you. I‚Äôve been slowly making my way through it for a few days, and it‚Äôs tough, but it‚Äôs eye-opening‚Äîin comparing where I was at the beginning of the year to where I am now, I‚Äôm starting to see more clearly what‚Äôs really important to me, and where my energy will be best spent next year. The workbook is currently on sale for $5, go give Haley your money!

‚Äì Jillian

entry.title: Letter 26
entry.content:
üéâ Today is our newsletter‚Äôs first birthday! We sent out our first letter exactly a year ago‚Äîpretty cool. Thanks for being here with us.

This week, we knew we had to talk about Pokemon Sword and Shield, which is pretty much all either one of us has been thinking about for the past week. Remember when we had that long chat about Animal Crossing for Letter 16? This is another one of those. You‚Äôre welcome.


Ummm ok so to start us off

When we planned to do this, I wasn‚Äôt planning on buying the new Pokemon game

But then I did and I played it all weekend

Jillian

It be like that sometimes

Summer

BUT I still have lots and lots of questions for you!!! Because you‚Äôve been playing Pokemon for a long time and I‚Äôve pretty much never played a Pokemon game before

My first question for u: a few weeks ago, you tweeted ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think any starters should be available in different gens gjsodnsodnf‚Äù

What dis mean

Jillian

Thank you for that direct quote

So! Every pokemon game kind of has the same formula. You‚Äôre a 10 year old kid and that means you‚Äôre old enough to have a pokemon of your own! The inciting incident to getting your first pokemon varies, but you always receive it from the professor of the region. The professor will have three pokemon for you to choose from: a grass type, a water type, or a fire type. The majority of the time, the moment in which you choose is the unique incidence of any of those pokemon throughout the game. Your rival will also choose one of the three. These pokemon have pretty steady level growth, balanced stats, good moves, and are cute! You can‚Äôt catch them in the wild. You get them from the professor. They are SPECIAL.

Summer

Ohhhhh ok

Jillian

You form such a lovely bond with your starter! It‚Äôs your FIRST pokemon and they occur in EVERY generation. Like, yes we get it, everyone loves Charizard. I do too! So much! But it doesn‚Äôt need to be available all of the time. Use Scorbunny. There are other cool fire types in this generation. The nostalgia pull seems unnecessary and sort of takes away from the specialness of a starter if they are obtainable across generations.

Summer

Hmmmm does this tie into the drama about some Pokemon not being available in the new game or am I getting ahead of myself

Jillian

WE CAN GO THERE FOR SURE

Summer

Lmao we WILL go there

Jillian

How do you want to get into the drama?

Summer

I don‚Äôt really know much about the drama other than‚Ä¶‚Ä¶.there was some

Specifically with the release of Sword and Shield

Which is odd to me because it seems like such a great game that all my friends love, but I‚Äôm also viewing that from the perspective of someone who doesn‚Äôt really have any ties to the franchise

So I wanna hear about it from your perspective

Tell me about the drama babyyy!!!!!

Jillian

Basically, after you beat the elite four in the majority of pokemon games, you get a thing called a national dex that has spaces for EVERY POKEMON that exists rather than those exclusive to that region/game. SWSH doesn‚Äôt have a national dex and people are super upset! On the one hand, I get it, when the catchphrase is ‚Äúgotta catch em all.‚Äù However.

The deep, deep entitlement of gamers is soooo toxic. I‚Äôm not a big completionist type, but there‚Äôs still a pokedex to fill up. There are so many other lovely things to enjoy and we had so much to look forward to with this game‚Äîthe fact that people were so violently upset with this decision was really disheartening

Summer

Hmmm ok so you‚Äôre telling me I can‚Äôt get every pokemon that‚Äôs ever existed in this new game, but there‚Äôs still like‚Ä¶‚Ä¶a lot of pokemon in it anyway

Jillian

YES

I also think people are upset their specific favorites aren‚Äôt available, but it‚Äôs been like that across every game! You have to trade from weird places, across consoles even! (In the GBA era, to finish the national dex you had to hook up to the gamecube)

Summer

I kind of understand where people are coming from, especially if they have deep nostalgic ties to certain pokemon that they‚Äôve taken with them over many generations of the game, etc etc.

But also there are so many cuties and sweeties in this game! And it‚Äôs kind of exciting to see all the new ones!

Are there any specific pokemon that aren‚Äôt in this game that you miss?

Jillian

Honestly, no. I barely notice what isn‚Äôt available. I try to just use new pokemon on my team? Because I want to familiarize myself with the region. I‚Äôve been pleasantly surprised at what IS available, actually. I saw a video on Twitter of a Lucario in SWSH and freaked out because I LOVE LUCARIO

Summer

I do fully understand the instinct to distrust and critique big game studios, right? But I‚Äôm also really tired of the stereotypical toxic gamer who can‚Äôt just enjoy a cute, fun game without complaining about all of the reasons it isn‚Äôt exactly what they wanted!!! I‚Äôm not sure how to balance those two feelings

BUT I think we‚Äôve established that the game is good and fun and people should calm down and enjoy it

We‚Äôve both been playing it a lot since it came out so I can definitely endorse it as Good and Fun. Anyway.

Jillian

Absolutely! And I have some criticisms, but nothing that is keeping me from being so overjoyed that I have it.

Summer

I was kind of struggling with deciding which game to get, once I decided I wanted to play it. I went with Sword mostly because sword dog but also because you picked Shield. Why did you decide to get Shield?

Jillian

This is the most I‚Äôve ever struggled with picking a version, strangely enough.

Summer

Oooh why?

Jillian

I, too, love sword dog and was immediately enamored. But there were a few version exclusives that I was into‚Äîlike Galarian Ponyta and Goomy‚Äîbut mostly, it was because of my brother! We have, traditionally, always gotten opposing versions. And we‚Äôve never even had a problem deciding who got what‚Äîgenerally we were always drawn to different legendaries. But he really wanted Sword because of Sirfetch‚Äôd and it felt wrong to not continue our sibling tradition, even though we don‚Äôt live together.

Summer

Omg aw that‚Äôs very cute

Jillian

We did pick the same starter for the first time!!!!

Summer

Wait who did you pick I don‚Äôt remember

Jillian

Grookey üêµ

Summer

Ahhhhhh!

All the starters are extremely cute

I am very happy with my Sobble that I refuse to evolve

Jillian

In their first forms, I agree. I did choose Grookey because his last form was the least terrifying, to me.

Summer

That‚Äôs such a good way to do it

Ok what was the first pokemon game you ever played

Jillian

So! I would play my brother‚Äôs copy of Pokemon Blue, but he wouldn‚Äôt let me restart it so I would just catch Rattatas and I didn‚Äôt know how to save so I would just turn the power off. That doesn‚Äôt super count, I guess, and maybe neither does Pokemon Stadium for N64, so Pokemon Ruby!!! 3rd gen.

Summer

Wow you go alllllll the way back huh

What‚Äôs your FAVORITE pokemon game

And least favorite?

Jillian

Oof. My nostalgia brain wants to say Pokemon Emerald, since it has some of the best post-game and I know that generation inside-out. I also love all three of those starters, even if I choose Torchic more often than not. I think XY is my least favorite‚Äîthe graphics were so cool and the pokemon were also great, but I thought the new mechanics made it too easy and I was really frustrated. There‚Äôs not a lot of post-game either.

Generally I feel like I will love a pokemon no matter what? So what makes a game for me is the story‚Äîand I think difficulty level is built into that.

Summer

Do you often replay pokemon games?

Or do you just keep playing one forever? Or do you let it end and wait for the next one?

Jillian

I‚Äôve played gen 1-4 over an EXCEPTIONAL amount of times, especially Gen 1 by way of FireRed. I clocked soooo many hours on Emerald specifically, even in the post-game‚Äînot super sure what I was doing, to be honest, but when you‚Äôre roughly 10 you have so much patience to do so many things. Replaying was great because there were so many new team combinations to explore!!!

Summer

This sort of touches on something that I was wondering, especially now that I‚Äôm in the trenches of a pokemon game, which is: do pokemon games‚Ä¶‚Ä¶.end?

Jillian

I guess it depends on how you define winning? You can beat the elite four, which technically makes you the champion, as many times as you want. Gens 3 and 4 had ‚Äúpokemon contests‚Äù, which were like beauty pageants in a few different categories; each pokemon can compete and get ribbons and stuff, etc etc.

Completing your pokedex is another definition people have

Theoretically, I can be happy with rechallenging the elite four over and over again, which is what I was doing in XY and Let‚Äôs Go. And in something like FireRed/LeafGreen, being the champion opens up a whole new set of areas to explore! So that‚Äôs not always the conclusion.

Summer

So you can pretty much keep going forever?

Jillian

Basically! Each game has different ways to make it interesting, but yeah. The final boss battle will always be open to you

Summer

nice, I like that

Do you think SW/SH is a good pokemon game for beginners? Or would you recommend starting somewhere different?

Jillian

I think it is, and I think it‚Äôs definitely designed to be easy to grasp as possible. Hop is a constant tutorial character, unfortunately.

Summer

He is‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶.annoying

In a brotherly way I guess

Jillian

HE IS!!!!

Summer

Pls give me your tips for pokemon newbies like myself

Jillian

I strongly encourage having a balanced team and understanding typing as well as you can. I also recommend reading the pokedex online and familiarizing yourself with a region! I get people don‚Äôt like spoilers, but it‚Äôs really beneficial to learn what pokemon you want early on and where to find them, so there are no regrets. I get really attached to pokemon and am reluctant to make team adjustments, so knowing apple dragon, for example, existed was good!

Summer

Summer I am literally reading the pokedex RIGHT NOW because of you!!!!!

I think we both know how I feel about ‚Äúspoilers‚Äù in video games which is: look up as much stuff as you want, who cares, I just like to follow directions

I want to end this the same way we ended our conversation about animal crossing which is: tell me about your favorite pokemon memory!

Jillian

THIS IS SO HARD! Pokemon is my whole life. My first thought was playing Pokemon Go with my brother when it first came out, and our UTTER JOY at seeing a goddamn sandshrew on our driveway with the AR function. We were literally jumping in glee!!!! We are adults!!!! I used pokemon to make friends when I moved to California. My closest friends all gave me pokemon plushies as a present when I left Michigan. I got two Pikachu-based gifts when I graduated college. I have love tied to every aspect of the franchise: the games, the anime, etc.

I am so happy you have joined this journey

Summer

I‚Äôm super happy to be on this pokemon journey too

Thank u for teaching me stuff

Jillian

I am here to answer every question. I have to do something with all of this knowledge in my head.

Summer

this was fun but the whole time I was like‚Ä¶‚Ä¶I can‚Äôt wait to‚Ä¶‚Ä¶play pokemon after this

Jillian

RIGHT

My switch was charging‚Ä¶.it‚Äôs time

Summer

Ok I‚Äôm gonna go do that

‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è

Jillian
